EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



TYSON FRESH MEATS INC.  AMARILLO, TEXAS



1.  Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy



It is the policy of the Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc. (Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc) Amarillo, Texas facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 and with the corresponding regulations under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc employees, the public and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating procedures, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.  This plan covers all Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc owned activities at this facility.

Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc's management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.



2.  Facility Description



Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc operates a cattle slaughter and processing facility and a hides tannery at this location.  Cattle are trucked to the facility, slaughtered and fabricated.  Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc operates rendering systems to produce gel bone, dried blood, high and low protein beef byproducts, tallow, and other rendering products.  Support operations include a wastewater treatment system, truck repair facilities, cold storage, an analytical laboratory, and administrative offices.

Three chemicals are utilized at the facility in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.  These chemicals are ammonia, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.  Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in systems located throughout the facility. Methane and hydrogen sulfide (both are commonly referred to as Biogas) are produced as a re

sult of anaerobic treatment of process wastewater.



3.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



The Amarillo, Texas facility is governed by a set of OSHA and USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities intended to prevent a release of hazardous material, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to the employees of the facility, the public and to the environment.  These regulations include:

* 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention

* 40 CFR Part 112, Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure

* 40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan

* 29 CFR Part 119, Process Safety Management

* 40 CFR Part 302, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)

The key concepts in Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc's release prevention program are employee participation, appropriate design and maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees.  Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc has developed and documented these elements in their process safety management plan (PSM).  The PSM plan is incorporated with this document by reference.

Employee participation in the release-prevention program is encouraged and supported by Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc management.  Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the ammonia systems and biogas system.  Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc employees are also members of the facility emergency response team.

Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc policy is to construct all new equipment, systems, and facilities to ensure the appropriate safety and release prevention systems are included from the beginning of each project.  Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc maintains a computerized program of maintenance activities to ensure that key systems are maintained appropriately to minimize the risk of a release.

Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc is committed to providing appropriate training to all employ

ees regarding safety procedures.  Each new employee is provided comprehensive safety training during their initial orientation for the facility.  In addition, Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc conducts regularly scheduled safety training for all employees each year.  Additional training is provided to maintenance personnel related to systems for which they are responsible.  Members of Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc's emergency response team receive annual training to ensure that response actions are promptly and safely completed.



4.  Five Year Accident History



Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc experienced no reportable accidents covered by EPAA?s RMP rule at the Amarillo, Texas facility in the five-year period leading up the to the update of this RMP plan.



5.  Emergency Response Program



Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc has personnel trained in emergency response at the facility 24 hours per day, seven days per week.  These personnel receive annual training on emergency procedures and response techniques.



6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc completes a thorough review of the ammonia and biogas systems each time a design change is implemented.  Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc is committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of these systems.
